title: Bilateral Otosclerosis Progression with Dizziness
chief_complaint: My hearing has recently decreased in both ears and sounds are distorted even when I turn up my hearing aids. I am also experiencing dizziness when I stand up or turn my head quickly in bed.

problem_summary.onset: Recent decrease in hearing; dizziness is a new concern.
problem_summary.course: Hearing has steadily decreased; otosclerosis has progressed.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Sound distortion, dizziness (orthostatic and positional), constant bilateral tinnitus, intermittent sensation of pressure/fluid.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Patient has to increase hearing aid volume significantly; concerned about ability to drive due to dizziness.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Wants to hear better and resolve dizziness/driving concerns.

history.present_illness: Patient reports recent bilateral hearing decrease and distortion. Notes dizziness upon standing and when turning head quickly in bed. Intermittent pressure/fluid sensation reported.
history.medical_psych_history: Reports dizziness consistent with orthostatic hypotension (standing up) and BPPV (turning in bed).
history.prior_management: Currently uses hearing aids but has to increase volume significantly.
history.patient_goals: Improve hearing clarity and address dizziness.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Severe mixed loss (250-1500 Hz), rising to moderately severe SNHL at 2000 Hz, sloping to severe/profound mixed at high frequencies. Left ear: Profound mixed loss (250-500 Hz), rising to severe (1000-2000 Hz), sloping to profound. Masking dilemmas noted due to magnitude of loss and air-bone gaps.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT revealed severe loss bilaterally, in agreement with PTA. WRS revealed very poor ability to recognize speech bilaterally.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Immittance testing was not measured due to previous otosurgery.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with severe-to-profound mixed hearing loss bilaterally, indicating progression of otosclerosis despite prior surgery. Speech recognition scores are very poor (30-40%), suggesting limited benefit from traditional amplification. The patient also exhibits symptoms consistent with Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV).
counseling_points: Explain that the otosclerosis has progressed, resulting in mixed hearing loss that is now difficult to manage with standard hearing aids.
Discuss Cochlear Implant (CI) candidacy as a strong option given the poor speech discrimination and severity of loss.
Counsel on BPPV (positional dizziness) and recommend/perform the Epley maneuver.
Advise on safety precautions regarding driving and fall prevention due to dizziness.
Recommend continued use of hearing protection in noise and annual monitoring.
notes_for_actor: Portray an elderly male (approx 78 years old).
You are frustrated that your hearing aids aren't working well anymore; voices sound distorted.
Describe two distinct types of dizziness: one when you stand up too fast, and a 'spinning' sensation when you roll over in bed.
Mention that the tinnitus (ringing) is constant but you mostly notice it at night when the hearing aids are out.
